```

# incremental
mod = mx.mod.Module(symbol=symbol, context=devs, arg_params=xxx, aux_params=xxx)  # you might want to push the params also
# fit/train again
mod.fit()
```

Hello,

I too have run into this issue.  I've discovered that the proposal_target operator is only implemented in python https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/rcnn/rcnn/symbol/proposal_target.py#L14 and thus is holding me back from running my network in C++.
I will probably be looking into implementing this in C++ soon.

This seems to be fixed by compiling with the makefile build instead of cmake and by making sure DMSHADOW_USE_PASCAL = 1
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/6204

Hi, I suppose you have cuda 8.0 and used the latest version of mxnet.
I ran into the same problem, and it turns out that cublasCgemm3mStridedBatched is a function of cuda v8.0.61. Check your cuda version. To solve the problem, you can either update cuda to latest version, or try with an older mxnet(before jun 2, when cuda v8.0.61 was released).

@thirdwing  @Mrugankakarte 

I am also getting same prediction value for binary classification problem when I use RMSPROP optimizer. When I tried using SGD, output is fine. 

In terms of training, running with both optimizers for 50 rounds with learning rate of 0.01. 

Comparison in terms of error metric: 

Optimizer                 Beginning RMSE                  Ending RMSE
rmsprop                     0.4728                                  0.4640
sgd                             0.4542                                  0.4331

Could you please help me out here. Thanks.

Please try to code below. It extracted the `global_pooling_feature`, which you used later.

```r
library(mxnet)
prefix = "Inception-BN"
num.round = 126
model = mx.model.load(prefix, num.round)
internals = model$symbol$get.internals()
fea_symbol = internals[[match("global_pool_output", internals$outputs)]]

model2 <- list(symbol = fea_symbol,
              arg.params = model$arg.params,
              aux.params = model$aux.params)

class(model2) <- "MXFeedForwardModel"

library(imager)

im <- load.image(system.file("extdata/parrots.png", package = "imager"))
plot(im)

preproc.image <- function(im, mean.image) {
  # crop the image
  shape <- dim(im)
  short.edge <- min(shape[1:2])
  xx <- floor((shape[1] - short.edge) / 2)
  yy <- floor((shape[2] - short.edge) / 2)
  croped <- crop.borders(im, xx, yy)
  # resize to 224 x 224, needed by input of the model.
  resized <- resize(croped, 224, 224)
  # convert to array (x, y, channel)
  arr <- as.array(resized) * 255
  dim(arr) <- c(224, 224, 3)
  # subtract the mean
  normed <- arr - mean.img
  # Reshape to format needed by mxnet (width, height, channel, num)
  dim(normed) <- c(224, 224, 3, 1)
  return(normed)
}

mean.img <- 127

normed <- preproc.image(im, mean.img)

global_pooling_feature <- predict(model2, X = normed)
dim(global_pooling_feature)
```
Please also see #775

LGTM. I applied these changes and change the conflicts: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/6805

@CNevd for Nadam you seem to assume that `\hat g = g, \hat m = m, \hat n = n`. Can you clarify why you do this? Comparing to Algorithm 8 from the [paper](http://cs229.stanford.edu/proj2015/054_report.pdf) it seems wrong?

@leezu we implement nadam assume that u^t and v^t is small as [nadam_optimizer.py](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/03beb65cecbc1e49ea477bca7f54543134b31d53/tensorflow/contrib/opt/python/training/nadam_optimizer.py) does or we can change it to Algorithm 8 from the paper just like [keras-nadam](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/cc8b0f7fa972b8b73f0178bcfdb94106ba894187/tensorflow/contrib/keras/python/keras/optimizers.py#L550)
@CNevd let's wait for a comment from @piiswrong @sxjscience . If we choose to go with this assumption we should document it, as currently the docstring suggests that we follow the papers approach.

So the problem here is just that `ctypes.CDLL` can't find the libcuda. Could you try the following?
```
find / -type f -name libcuda.so.* -exec dirname {} \; 2>/dev/null
```
The above command prints the paths to libcuda.so.*, and you can append those to your LD_LIBRARY_PATH variable to fix the issue. Otherwise, you may want to look into installing cuda again since the libcuda isn't available on your system.
op.h was removed in pr #5573. @cjolivier01 @piiswrong

This usually indicates a problem in the driver and cuda installation. Do you happen to have multiple versions of cuda/nvidia driver installed on your host? Or is your nvcc a later version than the cuda you use at runtime? You may try and sift through the directories in LD_LIBRARY_PATH to see whether this is a problem.

It requires having the same indexer for words across different models. Specifically, suppose you want to share a pretrained word-embedding of vocabulary size `K`, each of dimension `d`:
1. use the indexer to index the `K` words (i.e "word" -> index such as 0, 1 ...K-1)
```
# suppose word2vec = {w: v_ddim}
idx2w = list(word2vec.keys())
w2idx = {w: i for i, w in enumerate(idx2w)}
```
2. create the weight for embedding and use it perform look up.
```
weight = nd.array(word2vec.values())
sentence = 'hello world'.split()
sent_idx = nd.array([w2idx[w] for w in sentence])
sent_weights = nd.Embedding(data = sent_idx, weight = weight)
```
3. and in your new model, just remember to index the sentence using the same indexers (`idx2w and w2idx`.

If you have a trained model, then the weight matrix of that embedding layer has a layout of (num_words, num_embedding_dims), with the index as the key for the first dimension. You may simply pass that weight matrix to your next model and use the same indexer to access it. If you use symbol API, when you trained the old model, remember to either declare its weight as a variable, or give a unique name to the embedding layer. If you declare the weight as a variable, the weight matrix will simply be that variable. Or if you gave a the embedding layer a name, such as 'layer', the weight variable will have name 'layer_weight'. If you did neither, mxnet will automatically assign a unique name to it such as "embedding0_weight", in which case you will need to find it yourself.
@szha   Thx. It's recommended to use 375.66 for Tesla P4, But I'm using 378.13. It's ok now.

Does the model seem to converge? Periodically high loss may just be the manifestation of the same ordering of training samples. Turning on shuffle (`shuffle=True` in ImageRecordIter) will most likely make the periodic loss increase go away since the order of training samples will be randomized.

Yes. The returned `RandomOrderAug` just applies the three transformations from ColorJitterAug in random order. See https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/image.py#L351. And yes, the returned object is a function that you can call. The way the transformation is applied depends on the implementation of those augmentation, see https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/image.py#L369-L399.

@piiswrong @leezu update Nadam

Here is my guess:
I dig into the code for Speedometer, and there is a thrid parameter auto-reset which is true by default. It seems it would reset your metric when you call this callback. Then your number of instances becomes zero, and if that is exactly the end of the epoch, when you get the metric value, you would divide by 0, which returns NaN.

So, are you using auto-reset by default?
Seems that this issue has been fixed.
@ysh329 has the issue been fixed for you?
